HB100.name: Introduction to Hospitality Business
HB100.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HB100.description: Sectors, segments and disciplines of the hospitality and tourism industries. Impact of travel and tourism. Hospitality trends. Overview of accounting, marketing, and sales.
HB100.restrictions: Not open to juniors or seniors.

HB105.name: Service Management Principles
HB105.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HB105.description: Concept of service organizations. Key issues in delivering and managing services. Service intangibility. Needs, expectations, habituation and customer satisfaction. Prepurchase and postpurchase behaviors.
HB105.restrictions: Open to students in the Hospitality Business Major.

HB201.name: Hospitality Business Professional Development
HB201.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HB201.description: Self-assessment of personal and professional interests, skills, and values. Development of professional identity. Career exploration, planning, and development. Building professional relationships through networking and mentorships. Workplace competencies including diversity and multicultural awareness, interpersonal communication, team membership, and leadership.
HB201.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the School of Hospitality Business.

HB203.name: Hospitality Communication
HB203.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HB203.description: Effective hospitality business communication. Selecting appropriate formats for the audience. Developing and delivering effective presentations. Analyzing, writing and revising hospitality business documents. Spotting, correcting and avoiding common writing pitfalls.
HB203.restrictions: Open to students in the Hospitality Business Major.

HB207.name: Hospitality Management and Leadership
HB207.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HB207.description: Overview of management and leadership theories and applications specific to the hospitality industry. Discussion of leadership principles, management principles, change management, decision-making, communications, motivational theories, and negotiation skills.
HB207.restrictions: Open to students in the Hospitality Business Major.

HB210.name: Introduction to the Casino Industry
HB210.description: Social issues of gaming, casino games of chance, management controls and marketing plans.

HB237.name: Management of Lodging Systems
HB237.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HB237.description: Interrelated systems in lodging operations for front desk/guest services, reservations, housekeeping, engineering, sales/conference services, accounting, security as well as food and beverage. Segmentation of lodging products and associated management challenges.

HB265.name: Food Management: Safety and Nutrition
HB265.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HB265.description: Standards of microbiology, sanitation, nutrition, and other quality issues in food management. Chemical, health, and workplace standards. Management of product quality and costs.

HB267.name: Management of Food and Beverage Systems
HB267.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HB267.description: Principles of menu planning, designing and pricing. Control of food and beverage products during purchasing, receiving, storing and issuing. Labor control principles. Control of revenue during sale. Food and beverage segment overview.

HB293.name: Cooperative Education for Business Students
HB293.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HB293.description: Integration of pre-professional educational employment experiences in industry and government with knowledge and processes taught in the student's academic program. Educational employment assignment approved by the Department of Supply Chain Management.

HB302.name: Hospitality Managerial Accounting
HB302.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HB302.description: Principles of managerial accounting applied to hospitality enterprises. Topics include financial statements, forecasting methods, internal control, and ethics.
HB302.restrictions: Open to sophomores or juniors or seniors in the Hospitality Business Major.

HB307.name: Hospitality Human Resources
HB307.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HB307.description: Human resource management and interpersonal skills in the hospitality industry. Managing in a culturally diverse workplace. Benefits, compensation, employee and labor relations, equal opportunity, ethics, interviewing, job analysis and description, labor laws, performance management and appraisal, personnel planning, recruitment, retention, risk management, strategic planning, talent management, testing and selection, training and development.
HB307.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Hospitality Business Major.

HB311.name: Hospitality Finance
HB311.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HB311.description: Optimal management of a hospitality firm's assets and financing requirements. Analysis of financial statements, financial markets, risk, valuation, short-term and long-term financing and investment.
HB311.restrictions: Open to sophomores or juniors or seniors in the Hospitality Business Major or in the Hospitality Business Real Estate Investment Management Minor.

HB320.name: Casino Operations and Management
HB320.description: Practices and problems associated with casino management. Staffing, security, protection of table games, and control.
HB320.restrictions: Open to students in the School of Hospitality Business.

HB321.name: Club Operations and Management
HB321.description: Club operations and management. City, country, yacht, and athletic clubs.
HB321.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Hospitality Business Major.

HB337.name: Hospitality Information Systems
HB337.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HB337.description: Technology for gathering, analyzing, storing and communicating information within the hospitality industry.
HB337.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Hospitality Business Major.

HB345.name: Quantity Food Production Systems
HB345.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HB345.description: Organization of food and beverage operations. Product knowledge, especially purchasing, storing, preparing and production in food service operations. Menu development and recipe management.
HB345.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the School of Hospitality Business.

HB345L.name: Quantity Food Production Systems Laboratory
HB345L.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HB345L.description: Practical applications of organization in food and beverage operations. Product knowledge, especially purchasing, storing, preparing, and production in food service operations. Menu development and recipe management.
HB345L.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the School of Hospitality Business.

HB347.name: The Foodservice Distribution Channel
HB347.description: Business and management of the foodservice distribution channel. Relationships among foodservice manufacturers, brokers, and distributors. Value-added services. Request for proposal (RFP) process. Current issues and future trends.
HB347.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the School of Hospitality Business.

HB349.name: Facilities Maintenance and Systems
HB349.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HB349.description: Managing the physical plant of a hospitality business. Key systems, safety, preventive maintenance, energy conservation.
HB349.restrictions: Open to sophomores or juniors or seniors in the School of Hospitality Business.

HB358.name: Hospitality Business Ownership
HB358.description: Hospitality business ownership qualities and characteristics. Thinking like an owner and resultant actions. Ownership responsibilities across all functional areas of the hospitality entrepreneur business.
HB358.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the School of Hospitality Business.

HB375.name: Hospitality Marketing
HB375.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HB375.description: Marketing of hospitality products and services in an increasingly competitive, global, and culturally diverse market.
HB375.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the School of Hospitality Business.

HB376.name: Hospitality Sales Process
HB376.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HB376.description: Management of the sales process in the hospitality industry.
HB376.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Hospitality Business Major.

HB380.name: Meeting and Event Planning and Management
HB380.description: Planning, developing, budgeting, promoting, delivering, and evaluating meetings or special events in the hospitality industry.
HB380.prerequisite: (HB 375 or concurrently) or (MKT 300 or concurrently) or (MKT 327 or concurrently)
HB380.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the School of Hospitality Business.

HB382.name: Hospitality Business Real Estate Investment Management
HB382.description: Process of planning and developing a commercial real estate project
HB382.restrictions: Open to sophomores or juniors or seniors in the School of Hospitality Business or approval of school.

HB393.name: Introduction to International Business
HB393.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HB393.description: Introduction to the context of international business delivered on-site in foreign settings. Fundamental concepts and principles of globalization such as multinational corporations, foreign markets and economies, internal and external market transactions, international law, cultural influences, and multinational business strategies.
HB393.restrictions: Open to students in the Eli Broad College of Business and The Eli Broad Graduate School of Management or in the School of Hospitality Business.

HB405.name: Advanced Management of Food and Beverage Systems
HB405.description: Design of food and beverage control systems, emphasis on product purchasing (policies, suppliers, selection and evaluation, determination of quality and quantity, ethics and use of technology), inventory management and issuing systems, revenue control procedures and equipment.
HB405.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the School of Hospitality Business.

HB409.name: Introduction to Wine
HB409.description: Introduction to wine with emphasis on primary varietals and blends, legal nomenclature, classes of wine, and wine production. Potential health implications of wine consumption and socio-cultural and historical facts. Wine and food matching and tools and approaches for wine and food matching. Sensory assessment is discussed. No alcohol is consumed in this course.
HB409.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

HB411.name: Hospitality Beverages
HB411.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HB411.description: Evaluation and selection of hospitality beverages. Geographical origins of beverages, beverage production, quality assessment, matching beverages with food, health and social considerations.
HB411.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Hospitality Business Major. Approval of school.

HB415.name: Managing Quality in Hospitality Businesses
HB415.description: Quality management and leadership in hospitality businesses. Quality planning and improvement, assessment, internal and external customer surveys and feedback, costs of quality, strategic quality planning.
HB415.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the School of Hospitality Business.

HB420.name: The Business of Golf
HB420.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HB420.description: Accounting, branding, expensing, logistics, negotiations, recruiting, risk management, operations, and promotion in golf. Business considerations in the development and location of golf courses.
HB420.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

HB437.name: Hospitality Revenue Management
HB437.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HB437.description: Exposure to key management and marketing issues relating to the effective implementation of revenue management. The relationships between the revenue management function and other functions or departments in the hospitality organization. The role and job responsibilities of a revenue manager. The identification of distribution channels that hospitality organizations may use to distribute their inventory.
HB437.prerequisite: ((HB 273 or concurrently) or (ITM 209 or concurrently)) and (HB 375 or MKT 300 or MKT 327)
HB437.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Hospitality Business Major or in the Hospitality Business Real Estate Investment Management Minor.

HB447.name: Hospitality Business Law
HB447.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HB447.description: Legal aspects of hospitality industry, including structure of the U.S. legal system, contracts, torts, discrimination, property and product liability. Administrative law and government regulation of the industry.
HB447.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Hospitality Business Major.

HB451.name: Emerging Leadership
HB451.description: Emerging hospitality business leadership challenges. Personal qualities and essentials. Integrity. Diversity. Emerging leadership process. Leadership in hospitality business organizations.
HB451.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the School of Hospitality Business.

HB473.name: Hospitality Business Analytics
HB473.description: Quantitative and analytical skills used to communicate key business information effectively. Study of how business modeling and data analytics can increase decision making efficacy. Course topics include but are not limited to sensitivity and scenario analysis, financial modeling and forecasting, and applied business statistics methods.
HB473.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the School of Hospitality Business.

HB482.name: Advanced Hospitality Finance
HB482.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HB482.description: Cash flow determination and management. Strategies for financing hospitality ventures and expansion. Determining financial viability of proposed and existing operations.
HB482.prerequisite: ((HB 273 or concurrently) or (ITM 209 or concurrently)) and (HB 311 or FI 311 or FI 320)
HB482.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Hospitality Business Major or in the Hospitality Business Real Estate Investment Management Minor.

HB485.name: Hospitality Foodservice Operations
HB485.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HB485.description: Beverage management and dining room service. Guest relations and current management topics. Emphasis on foodservice team projects.
HB485.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Hospitality Business Major.

HB486.name: Advanced Hospitality Marketing
HB486.description: Application of advanced marketing principles in the hospitality industry. Identifying, influencing and servicing demand for hospitality products, services, and experiences.
HB486.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Hospitality Business Major.

HB489.name: Hospitality Business Strategy (W)
HB489.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HB489.description: Management problems and issues in the hospitality industry. Focus on decision-making models. Case study analysis, discussion and report writing.
HB489.prerequisite: (HB 307 or MGT 315) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
HB489.restrictions: Open to seniors in the Hospitality Business Major.

HB490.name: Independent Study
HB490.description: Supervised research in hospitality management and operations.
HB490.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the School of Hospitality Business. Approval of school.

HB491.name: Current Topics in Hospitality Business
HB491.description: Emerging topics or issues confronting the hospitality service industry.
HB491.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the School of Hospitality Business.

HB492.name: Hospitality Business Real Estate Professional Skills Workshop
HB492.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HB492.description: Specific knowledge and analytical skills necessary to be successful in an analyst role with a consulting, real estate development, or investment advisory organization. Workshop topics include but are not limited to hospitality real estate investment, market valuation, Excel modeling, business writing, financing hospitality enterprises, asset management, and hotel industry data analytics.
HB492.restrictions: Open to students in the Hospitality Business Real Estate Investment Management Minor or approval of school.

HB801.name: Seminar in Hospitality Business
HB801.description: Issues of critical importance to hospitality business.

HB807.name: Workforce Management in the Hospitality Industry
HB807.description: Identifying and solving hospitality workforce problems. Topics include leadership styles, interpersonal and organization communication.
HB807.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Eli Broad College of Business and The Eli Broad Graduate School of Management.

HB837.name: Hospitality Information Technology
HB837.description: Overview of computer systems and networks designed for the hospitality industry.
HB837.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Eli Broad College of Business and The Eli Broad Graduate School of Management.

HB841.name: Contemporary Trends in Cuisine and Culture
HB841.description: Contemporary trends in cuisine and culture from the perspectives of global impact on food safety, food marketing and distribution, food production and the cross cultural adaptation of cuisines throughout the world

HB847.name: Hospitality Business Law
HB847.description: Legal aspects of hospitality industry, including structure of the U.S. legal system, contracts, torts, discrimination, property and product liability. Administrative law and government regulation of the industry.
HB847.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Eli Broad College of Business and The Eli Broad Graduate School of Management.

HB882.name: Financial Management in the Hospitality Industry
HB882.description: Interpretation and analysis of financial statements. Budget preparation and analysis. Leasing, franchising, and management contracts.

HB885.name: Hospitality Business Research
HB885.description: Management principles and practices in hospitality businesses. Product, sales, service income, and human resource strategies.

HB886.name: Marketing in the Hospitality Industry
HB886.description: Understanding hospitality marketing in a global business environment. Industry responses to changing consumer trends. Applying marketing principles to case studies.
HB886.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Hospitality Business or in the Hospitality Business Specialization.

HB889.name: Hospitality Industry Field Study
HB889.description: Research on a current issue, problem or opportunity in a segment of the hospitality industry. Industry relationships and networking. Faculty supervision in a field setting.
HB889.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Eli Broad College of Business and The Eli Broad Graduate School of Management or approval of school.

HB890.name: Independent Study
HB890.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Eli Broad College of Business and The Eli Broad Graduate School of Management or approval of school.
